description: From Middle English mevement, from Old French movement (modern French mouvement), from movoir + -ment; cf. also Medieval Latin movimentum, from Latin movere (“move”). Doublet of moment and momentum. In this sense, displaced native Old English styring, which led to Modern English stirring.

entries.meaning: Physical motion between points in space.
examples: I saw a movement in that grass on the hill.

entries.meaning: (engineering) A system or mechanism for transmitting motion of a definite character, or for transforming motion, such as the wheelwork of a watch.
The impression of motion in an artwork, painting, novel etc.
A trend in various fields or social categories, a group of people with a common ideology who try together to achieve certain general goals
examples: The labor movement has been struggling in America since the passage of the Taft-Hartley act in 1947.

entries.meaning: (music) A large division of a larger composition.
(music) Melodic progression, accentual character, tempo or pace.
(aviation) An instance of an aircraft taking off or landing.
examples: Albuquerque International Sunport serviced over 200,000 movements last year.

entries.meaning: (baseball) The deviation of a pitch from ballistic flight.
examples: The movement on his cutter was devastating.

entries.meaning: (bridge) A pattern in which pairs change opponents and boards move from table to table in duplicate bridge.
An act of emptying the bowels.
(obsolete) Motion of the mind or feelings; emotion.
